video-config.troubleshootingIntro: If you're having any trouble getting your webcam set up, please email Dr Caspar Addyman <infantologist@gmail.com> with a brief description of the problem.

parentTextBlock.text: Here's what we want you to do.

video-consent.PIName: Dr Sinead Rocha and Dr Caspar Addyman
video-consent.institution: University of Cambridge and Goldsmiths, University of London, UK
video-consent.PIContact: Dr Sinead Rocha at sineadrocha@gmail.com or Dr Caspar Addyman at infantologist@gmail.com
video-consent.purpose: Whilst tapping along to our favourite song may seem automatic to us as adults, it is actually a pretty complex behaviour. We know that young children are brilliant at ‘sensing’ the rhythm of music but that they take some time to be able to coordinate their movement to it. We would like to know if the developing skill of toddlers to move in time with the beat of music is related to their general ability to monitor and adapt to the environment around them.
video-consent.procedures: We ask that your child is sat in a chair or highchair, within easy reach of a table. Your child will see some videos of a hand drumming (some fast, some slow) and will be asked to drum along on the table in front of them. There are no anticipated risks associated with participating.
video-consent.datause: We are interested in your child's ability to match the rhythms that they hear. We will use specialist software to measure the timing of your child’s movements. We will look at these data in light of your survey responses.
video-consent.payment:
Payment for participation through vouchers is not considered a benefit, it is compensation for participation. Within 14 days after participating in this study, we will email you a $5 Amazon gift card which you can exchange for credit at Amazon. To be eligible for the gift card, your child must be in the age range for this study, you need to submit a valid consent statement, and we need to see that there is a child with you. But we will send a gift card even if you do not finish the whole study or if we are not able to use your child's data.  

 We cannot promise any benefits to you or others from your taking part in this research. You will not receive results of the procedures and tasks your child performs as part of this research. Our conclusions are about how groups of children respond, and therefore individual results are not meaningful. However, possible benefits include learning more about research with children.
video-consent.Publication of results: The results of the research may be presented at scientific meetings or published in scientific journals. Raw data (for instance, the tempo of children's table hits) may be published when it cannot identify children. We never publish children's birthdates or names, and we never publish your demographic data in conjunction with your child's video.
video-consent.research_rights_statement: This research has been reviewed and approved by the ethics committee at Goldmiths, University of London. You should also know that you may contact any of the following people if you are unhappy about the way your data or your participation in this study are being treated: 1)  Goldsmiths Data Protection Officer – dp@gold.ac.uk  (concerning your rights to control personal data). 2) Chair, Goldsmiths Research Ethics and Integrity Sub-Committee - via reisc@gold.ac.uk, REISC Secretary (for any other element of the study). 3) You also have the right to lodge a complaint with the Information Commissioner’s Office at https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/
video-consent.gdpr_personal_data: your email address, child's date of birth
video-consent.gdpr_sensitive_data: your racial or ethnic origin, video images of you and your child

blocks.title: What you (parent or guardian) have to do:

listblocks.text: The most important role you have during the study is to make sure your child stays in front of the computer.
You can encourage them to keep drumming, but please do not show them what to do!

blocks.title: What to do when the study is finished:

listblocks.text: Once the study has finished playing, you’ll be given an opportunity to report any technical problems you may have experienced along the way.
Then, you be asked to select a privacy level for your videos.
Finally, we will take you to our questionnaire - you can complete this at a later date if preferred .

first-instructions.nextButtonText: I'm ready to get my child in position

blocks.title: What to do during the study:

listblocks.text: If your child gets fussy or distracted during the study, or you need to attend to something else for a moment, you can pause the study by pressing the spacebar.
If you notice that your child is becoming bored or too fussy to finish the study, that is perfectly OK and quite common. You are free to discontinue their participation in the study at any point.
If you need to end the study early, you can press ctr-X or the F1 key to end the study. Select “exit” in the box that will appear on the screen. This will take you to the end of the study.

Please make sure we have a good view of your little one during the study. The best position for your child would be in a highchair or similar, with you sitting next to them. Sitting on your lap is not ideal, as we adults tend to make tiny movements when listening to a beat, even if we are trying to sit still, and we don’t want these to influence your child’s movement.
Above is an example of what we would like to see - you will need some table space between your child and the computer, so you might need to push the computer a bit further back than normal.
Don’t worry if you feel your child becoming disinterested in the screen. Even if your child only drums a little bit, we are still collecting valuable data from your child.

webcamBlocks.title: It's time to get your child & check yourself out!

listblocks.text: Take a few moments to get settled and use the webcam preview to make sure your child’s whole upper body and some table space is in view. Also be sure that it isn’t too dark, and that you are not blocking the view of your child.
The green button down below will take you to the beginning of the study. So, press the button when you and your child are in position and ready to go.

second-instructions.nextButtonText: We are in position and ready to start!

listblocks.text: In this study your child will be asked to drum, both when there is nothing to copy, and then when they can see and hear another hand drumming.
On the next screen you will see an example of some children participating. Please ask your little one to watch this video to help them know what to do’
Are you in position?
Now it is time to get started! In the first video we would like your child to drum all by themselves. Please encourage them to drum, but do not show them what to do.

debriefing.title: Thank you for participating in our study!

blocks.title: What was this study about?
blocks.text:
Young children find moving in time with the beat quite a tricky skill to master! We are interested if this is related their ability to be flexible in their behaviour, and to match their behaviour to the environment around them. From these videos we will measure how your child changed their rhythm in response to the different tempos they saw and heard. And how this differed from their own 'natural rhythm', which we measured in the silent videos.

 The aim is to are trying to develop a new tool that can allow us to measure children’s rhythmic timing from home, in a standardised way. This will give us new insights into the cognitive skills that feed into our sense of rhythm.
